summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to T-Mobile USA, Inc., demanding telephone records for an investigation into suspected federal criminal violations, including 18 U.S.C. ยง 1519 and 371. The document includes a request for non-disclosure to preserve the confidentiality of the ongoing investigation.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued and signed the grand jury subpoena as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Authored the cover letter requesting non-disclosure and is involved in the grand jury investigation, though the specific name is not provided.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.context: The FBI agent to whom T-Mobile is instructed to deliver the requested records if personal appearance is waived.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, oversees the Assistant U.S. Attorney who is conducting the investigation and issued the subpoena.
The AUSA is working with an FBI Special Agent on the grand jury investigation, coordinating the collection of evidence.

events.title: Issuance of Grand Jury Subpoena
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office issued a grand jury subpoena to T-Mobile USA, Inc., demanding telephone records for an investigation into suspected federal felonies.

events.title: Scheduled Grand Jury Appearance
events.description: T-Mobile was commanded to appear before the grand jury to testify and produce records, though personal appearance could be waived by producing records to the FBI.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
T-Mobile USA, Inc. Law Enforcement Relations, 4 Sylvan Way, Parsippany, NJ 07504
United States Courthouse, 500 Pearl Street, Room 480, New York, NY
Federal Bureau of Investigation, 26 Federal Plaza, VCAC/Human Trafficking, New York, NY 10278
keyFacts: The subpoena is part of an official criminal investigation into suspected federal felonies, including violations of 18 U.S.C. ยง 1519 (destruction, alteration, or falsification of records) and 371 (conspiracy).
The U.S. Attorney's Office specifically requested T-Mobile not to disclose the existence of the subpoena to any third party to preserve the confidentiality of the investigation.

The subpoena demands extensive telephone records for the period from January 1, 2018, through the date of service, including call details, subscriber information, SMS/text messaging records, and IP history.
The document indicates the investigation involves human trafficking, as the FBI contact point is the VCAC/Human Trafficking unit in New York.
The subpoena allows T-Mobile to avoid a personal appearance by producing the requested records to an FBI Special Agent by the return date.
